qas.question: What methods, applied to the study of history, led to the perception of the Middle Ages as a time of recession and crisis?
Which author popularized a pessimistic view of the Late Middle Ages in his 1919 book?
What was the title of Huizinga's 1919 book on the Middle Ages?

answers.text: The Autumn of the Middle Ages

qas.question: Which countries were the focus of Huizinga's research?
What was the nationality of historian Henri Pirenne?
What methods, applied to the study of chemistry, led to the perception of the Middle Ages as a time of recession and crisis?
Which author popularized a pessimistic view of the Late Middle Ages in his 1991 book?

plausible_answers.text: The Autumn of the Middle Ages

qas.question: What was the title of Huizinga's 1819 book on the Middle Ages?
Which countries weren't the focus of Huizinga's research?
What wasn't the nationality of historian Henri Pirenne?

context: As <a0_0><b5_0>economic and demographic<b5_0/><a0_0/> methods were applied to the study of history, the trend was increasingly to see the late Middle Ages as a period of recession and crisis. <a4_0><b9_0>Belgian<b9_0/><a4_0/> historian Henri Pirenne continued the subdivision of Early, High, and Late Middle Ages in the years around World War I. Yet it was his Dutch colleague, <a1_0><b6_0>Johan Huizinga<b6_0/><a1_0/>, who was primarily responsible for popularising the pessimistic view of the Late Middle Ages, with his book <a2_0><b7_0>The Autumn of the Middle Ages<b7_0/><a2_0/> (1919). To Huizinga, whose research focused on <a3_0><b8_0>France and the Low Countries<b8_0/><a3_0/> rather than Italy, despair and decline were the main themes, not rebirth.
